review.title: A Neural Attention Model for Categorizing Patient Safety Events
review.abstract: Medical errors are leading causes of death in the US and as such, prevention of these errors is paramount to promoting health care. Patient Safety Event reports are narratives describing potential adverse events to the patients and are important in identifying and preventing medical errors. We present a neural network architecture for identifying the type of safety events which is the first step in understanding these narratives. Our proposed model is based on a soft neural attention model to improve the effectiveness of encoding long sequences. Empirical results on two large-scale real-world datasets of patient safety reports demonstrate the effectiveness of our method with significant improvements over existing methods.

sections.heading: 1 Introduction
sections.text: There is an increasing demand for textual electronic health records and clinical notes to promote medication, and as such, in recent years NLP / IR have become increasingly important for understanding, searching and analyzing medical information [22]. Human or system errors frequently occur in health centers, many of which can lead to serious harm to individuals. Indeed, there is an alarming number of annual deaths (up to 200K) reported due to medical errors [1]; medical errors are cited as the third leading cause of death in the U.S. [14]. Many health centers have deployed patient safety reporting systems to identify, mitigate and prevent errors.

sections.heading: 4 Conclusion
sections.text: We presented a neural network model based on a mechanism of soft attention to categorize event reports on patient safety. We demonstrated the effectiveness of our model on two large real-world datasets and made significant improvements over existing methods. The impact of our method and results on patient safety and healthcare is significant, as better categorization of events leads to better patient management and avoidance of harm to individuals.
